title.rendered: Hackers take over verified Twitter accounts to post NFTs

content.rendered:
Cryptocurrencies and NFTs are the target of multiple scams, something that is not really new, but that seems to gain value today. Now, hackers have targeted ‘moonbirds’ NFTs which have not yet lost all their value as most NFTs have.

It is a project of entrepreneurs Kevin Rose and Ryan Carson. It is a collection of 10,000 pixelated owls that have raised millions in sales in a few days. A real success that seems to have weathered the storm that NFTs are recently experiencing. After the opening of the NFT mint on Saturday, the project has registered more than 290 million dollars in sales on Opensea and Looksrare, a true fortune that hackers have been aware of, as reported by The Next Web.

To capitalize on this success, scammers have started to seize numerous verified accounts on Twitter and tweeting malicious links that could lead people to transfer their crypto or NFT hoping to get a Moonbird.

Most of the hacked accounts are North American, including those of Senator Levi Sanders, son of former US election candidate Bernie Sanders.
